title: WATCH — Should kids be allowed to vote?
text:
In some countries kids as young as 16 can vote

If you want to vote in the Canadian federal election on Oct. 21, you must be 18 or older.

At least for now.

In Canada, there’s been an ongoing debate over lowering the voting age for years.

But are kids informed enough to handle the responsibility?

CBC Kids News contributor Matthew Lupu hit the streets of Winnipeg to find out.

Watch the video above to see what happened!

CBC Kids News contributor Matthew Lupu speaks to kids in Winnipeg about the federal election. (Matthew Lupu/CBC)

An idea ‘worth considering’

The discussion began almost 50 years ago when it was lowered from 21 to 18.

Some Canadians even wondered back then, why stop there?

Former Miss Teen London, Kelsey Johnson, 18 at the time, at a Vote Mob gathering to encourage the youth vote in London, Ont., on April 30, 2011, for the federal election. (Dave Chidley/The Canadian Press)

While 18 is widely considered the "age of majority," kids across the country are granted other rights at age 16, such as driving a car.

So if kids are considered responsible enough to drive, have jobs and pay taxes, why can’t they vote at a younger age, too?

Tahja Ali, who wants to ‘help the environment,’ was nine years old when he participated in a mock student vote at Bel Ayr Elementary in Dartmouth, N.S. (Haydn Watters/CBC)

More than 10 countries that have lowered their voting age to 16, including Scotland, Austria, Cuba, Nicaragua, Argentina, Brazil and Ecuador.

According to Canada’s chief electoral officer, Stephane Perrault, it’s an idea “worth considering.”

"Voting when you're 16 is voting at a time when most Canadians at that age are still in school, at a place that we can actually get to them and engage them," he said in an interview with CBC in 2018.

A student in Burnaby, B.C., participates in a mock vote at her high school. (Civix)

Vancouver NDP MP Don Davies said many 16-year-olds work and pay taxes, yet they have no say in how those tax dollars are spent.

"Young people today are more involved, engaged and plugged into what's happening in our country and there's no reason they shouldn't be allowed to vote," he said in 2018.

The David Suzuki Foundation took the idea one step further by creating 18to8, a playful campaign that suggests eight-year-olds would vote with more wisdom than adults when it comes to prioritizing climate change.

18to8 is a satirical campaign launched by the David Suzuki Foundation that suggests eight-year olds should vote. (David Suzuki Foundation)

“Think lowering the voting age is crazy? Doing nothing is crazier,” reads the campaign website.

“We aren’t suggesting eight-year-olds should really get to vote, but we are suggesting that adults vote with the best interests of future generations in mind this October,” said David Suzuki Foundation CEO Stephen Cornish.

“Youth in Canada and around the world are speaking up, petitioning and organizing strikes to prioritize the climate crisis. Adults have the power to make changes. It’s time we listen to the young people.”

description: Should Canada lower its voting age from 18 to 16?
